title: Staging Systems: Hematologic Cancer Staging (NHL, HL, Leukemia)
summary: Comprehensive guide to staging systems for hematologic malignancies including lymphomas and leukemias.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Topic 6: Hematologic Cancer Staging (NHL, HL, Leukemia)

Hematologic malignancies differ fundamentally from solid tumors in that they often present with systemic or diffuse disease rather than a localized mass. Staging in these diseases reflects lymphatic involvement, bone marrow infiltration, organ spread, and disease biology.

items: Lymphomas use anatomic staging systems (Ann Arbor, Lugano).
Leukemias rely on molecular and risk-based classifications, not anatomical staging.
Imaging, PET/CT, and bone marrow assessment are essential components in most cases.

content.text: An evolution of the Ann Arbor system with integrated PET-CT imaging.

rows: Single lymph node region or a single extranodal site (IE)
Two or more lymph node areas on the same side of the diaphragm (II) or with contiguous extranodal spread (IIE)
Stage II with a bulky nodal mass (≥10 cm or >1/3 of chest diameter)
Lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (± spleen = IIIS)
Disseminated extralymphatic disease (e.g., liver, lungs, bone marrow)

items: A: No B symptoms
B: Presence of B symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats)
E: Extranodal extension
X: Bulky disease

content.text: Bone marrow biopsy is usually unnecessary if PET-CT is available and does not show marrow involvement.

items: IPS (International Prognostic Score) for advanced HL:
- Seven factors (e.g., low albumin, anemia, male sex, WBC >15,000)
- Score 0–1: 5-year OS ≥ 89%; Score 4–7: OS ≤ 61%
Limited-stage HL uses unfavorable risk factors such as:
- High ESR, bulky disease, ≥3 node regions, age ≥50

content.text: Used for both indolent and aggressive NHL types.

rows: Single nodal group or a single extranodal site
≥2 nodal groups on the same side of the diaphragm
Nodes on both sides of the diaphragm or nodes + spleen involvement
Disseminated extranodal disease (e.g., liver, bone marrow)

items: PET-CT: For FDG-avid lymphomas (most aggressive NHLs)
CT scan: For indolent, non-FDG-avid lymphomas (e.g., CLL/SLL, marginal zone lymphoma)
Bone marrow biopsy: Usually required, unless PET shows marrow involvement
IPI (International Prognostic Index):
- Factors: Age >60, ECOG >1, Stage III/IV, LDH, extranodal disease
FLIPI/m7-FLIPI: For follicular lymphoma, integrating clinical and molecular markers

content.text: Histology and biology (e.g., BCL2, MYC, TP53 mutations) often outweigh anatomic stage in prognostic value.
Leukemias are not staged anatomically. They are instead classified using clinical features, cytogenetics, molecular mutations, and therapy response.

items: ELN 2022 classification (European LeukemiaNet):
- Favorable: NPM1 mutation without FLT3-ITD, core-binding factor leukemias
- Intermediate: Normal karyotype, IDH1/2 mutations
- Adverse: TP53 mutation, complex karyotype, RUNX1 mutation
Bone marrow blasts >20% define AML
MRD status post-therapy increasingly guides prognosis
Prognostic variables:
- Age, WBC count, CNS/testicular involvement
- Cytogenetics (e.g., BCR-ABL, t(12;21))
- MRD clearance is the strongest predictor of relapse
Pediatric ALL follows risk-adapted treatment protocols based on Day 8/29 MRD
Rai staging (USA):
- 0 (lymphocytosis only) → IV (thrombocytopenia)
Binet staging (Europe):
- A (≤2 sites) → C (cytopenia)
Molecular markers critical:
- del(17p)/TP53 mutations = poor prognosis
- IGHV mutation status = therapy selection
MRD assessment post-therapy predicts time to progression

content.text: Hematologic cancers require tailored staging systems. HL and NHL continue to use anatomical-based staging (Ann Arbor, Lugano), while leukemias rely entirely on biologic and molecular risk stratification. PET-CT and MRD have revolutionized staging accuracy, particularly in lymphoma and leukemia, respectively. Understanding both disease biology and staging nuance is essential for optimal patient management.
